Here are some more ideas for your learning program:

1. Conference attendance: Encourage members to attend tech conferences, meetups, or workshops. Attending conferences can help members network with other professionals in the industry, learn about the latest trends and technologies, and gain inspiration for their own projects.
2. Tech talks: Invite guest speakers to give talks on specific topics related to tech, such as machine learning, web development, or cybersecurity. Tech talks can help members gain insights from experts in the field, learn about new technologies and tools, and ask questions to deepen their understanding.
3. Code challenges: Create coding challenges that members can work on individually or in teams. Code challenges can help members apply their knowledge to real-world problems, practice their coding skills, and learn from others.
4. Coding bootcamps: Host coding bootcamps where members can learn a new skill or technology over a short period of time. Bootcamps can help members gain practical experience, learn from experts in the field, and network with other members.
5. Code review clubs: Create a code review club where members can review each other's code and provide constructive feedback. Code review clubs can help members improve their coding skills, learn new techniques, and gain a deeper understanding of programming concepts.
6. Group projects: Assign group projects to members where they can collaborate to build a software project, a website, or an app. Group projects can help members learn to work together, develop their project management skills, and gain practical experience in building software.

As for more ideas like the blog writing task, you could also consider creating a podcast or video series where members can share their knowledge and experience. Members can create short episodes on specific topics, interview experts in the field, or discuss current events in tech. This can help members develop their presentation skills, gain exposure to new ideas, and share their knowledge with a wider audience.

Sure, here are some more tasks similar to blog writing:

1. Write technical documentation: Assign members to write technical documentation for a project they are working on or for a technology they are learning. Technical documentation can help members practice their technical writing skills, learn how to explain complex concepts in simple terms, and improve their ability to communicate their ideas to others.
2. Create tutorials: Ask members to create tutorials on specific topics or technologies. Tutorials can be in the form of written guides, videos, or interactive demonstrations. Members can use their creativity to make their tutorials engaging and fun, and they can help others learn new skills and techniques.
3. Participate in coding challenges: Encourage members to participate in coding challenges hosted by other organizations or websites, such as HackerRank or LeetCode. Coding challenges can help members improve their coding skills, learn new techniques, and compete with others in a fun and engaging way.
4. Build a portfolio website: Assign members to build their own portfolio website to showcase their skills and projects. This task can help members learn web development skills, practice their design skills, and create a professional online presence.
5. Write case studies: Ask members to write case studies on a specific project or technology they have worked on. Case studies can help members develop their writing skills, learn how to analyze problems and solutions, and showcase their problem-solving abilities.
6. Conduct code reviews: Assign members to conduct code reviews for other members' projects. This task can help members improve their code analysis skills, learn how to provide constructive feedback, and gain exposure to different coding styles and techniques.

These tasks can help members develop their skills and knowledge in a fun and engaging way, while also contributing to their personal and professional growth.
You're welcome! If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask. Good luck with your development club!
what community platform should i use, whatsapp, discord or any other ? also i currently document everything on notion, what other options do i have?

Choosing a community platform largely depends on your club's needs and preferences. Both WhatsApp and Discord are popular communication platforms that offer group chat, voice, and video call features. WhatsApp is a more traditional messaging platform that is easy to use and offers end-to-end encryption, while Discord is more geared towards gaming and offers additional features such as screen sharing and server customization.

Other community platforms you might consider include Slack, Microsoft Teams, or Telegram. Slack and Microsoft Teams are more commonly used in professional settings and offer advanced features such as file sharing, task management, and integrations with other tools. Telegram is a secure messaging app that offers group chat, voice and video calls, and file sharing.

As for documentation, there are many other options besides Notion. Some popular alternatives include Google Docs, Dropbox Paper, Trello, Asana, or Airtable. These tools offer different features and integrations, so it's worth exploring them to see which one works best for your club's needs.
